div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
THE WAR. RUSSIAN REVERSE. TROOPS GRADUALLY RETIRING.
div.p: Tokio, April 14. Oyama reports that 2,000 Russian cavalry and infantry were encountered and defeated on the 12th inst. 30 miles to the east of Mukden. The enemy retreated northeast to- wards Hailungcheng, fighting every step. The Russians are gradually retiring along Kirin road. The positions are otherwise un- changed. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, April 14. Linievitch reports that the Russian cavalry raided the railway near Kaiyuan and demolish- ed the telegraphs. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE RIVAL FLEETS. REPORT OF FIGHTING DENIED. RUSSIANS GOING NORTH.
div.p: New York, April 14. A telegram from Manila has reached here. It states that Admiral Train, commanding the American Squadron, has received news of the arrival at Saigon yesterday morning of the Russian hospital-ship “Orel," having on board many wounded. (Reuter.)

Tokio, April 14. An Imperial ordinance proclaims an imme- diate state of siege over Maku Harbour, in the Pescadores Islands, which the Japanese are believed to be using as a base. The report of fighting off Saigon is officially denied. (Reuter.)
Vienna, April 14. A state of siege has been proclaimed at Mako. (Havas.)
London, April 14. Naval experts believoethat Rodjestvensky will pass eastward of Japan, in order to ap- proach Vladivostok from the east through the islands. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, April 14. (Official). The “Orel" had no wounded on board. (Reuter.)
Saigon, April 14. The Russian squadron is going towards the north. (Havas.)

div.head: NORTH SEA INCIDENT.
div.p: St. Petersburg April 14. Count Lamsdorff has just expressed to the Scandinavian Legation his regret that Rodjest- vensky’s fleet fired on the Norwegian S.S. "Aldebaran.” (Reuter.)

div.head: MOROCCO. THE ALGERIAN BOUNDARY.
div.p: Tangier, April 14. It is stated here that the Sultan of Morocco has replied to the French Mission declaring that he has already signed an agreement with France about the Algerian boundary. The other reforms must be referred to the Powers which signed the Madrid Convention whereby he was bound. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE FISCAL FIGHT. “MODUS VIVENDI" TO BE ARRANGED.
div.p: London, April 14. A meeting of Tariff Reform Members of Parliament, presided over by Mr. Chamberlain, appointed a deputation, headed by Mr. Chamberlain, to wait upon Mr. Balfour with a view to arranging a “modus vivendi.” It is understood that Mr. Chamberlain has decided for the present to confine his fiscal programme to the policy advocated by Mr. Balfour. The Duke of Devonshire and his supporters are regarded as irreconcilables. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN REFORM.
div.p: Baku, April 14. The new Governor-General of the Caucasus has convened representatives of all classes to confer with him with reference to judicial administrative reforms. He held out the pros- pect od the allotment of various Crown lands amongst the inhabitants. He announces that the Tsar has ordered a revision of the Arme- nian Church property question. (Reuter.)

div.head: MARSEILLES MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: Paris, April 14. The Council of State has validated the elections of 23 Municipal Councillors at Mar- seilles, among whom is M. Chanot, and has cancelled 13. (Havas.)
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld
A Council or Ministers will be held on Monday next, under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive.
H. M.’s First class Cruiser’ “Diadem" sailed from Suez yesterday bound to Aden, en route to China.

div.head: The Charity Bazaar
div.p: organised by M. and Mme M. Cattaoui, for the Israelite Hospital to be built at Abbassieh, has brought in a profit. of about L.E. 200.

div.head: Attempted Murder
div.p: The Alexandria Na- tive Tribunal has sentenced Mohamed Hassan el Faleh to 5 years' hard labour for the attempted murder of a native of the Behera.

div.head: Land Purchase
div.p: We bear that MM. Rasponi and Abignente, members of the Italian Chamber of Deputies, have bought Daoud Pasha's land at Ghezireh Tebadrak for L.E. 15,000.

div.head: Execution
div.p: The first execution at Alexan- dria in the newly-erected execution chamber at Hadra Prison will take place shortly, when the murderer Basscouni will undergo the extreme penalty of the law.

div.head: National Bank
div.p: The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has decided to allow the following securities to be quoted in the Official List-National Bank of Egypt, fur- ther issue of 50,000 shares of £10 each, fully paid, Nes. 200,001 to 250,000.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 12th Inst., of which 6 were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 2 French. The day's receipts were frs. 324,586.42, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 3,896,862.52.

div.head: Mariout
div.p: In the memory of the oldest inhabitants-and there are quite a number of centenarians there--this year's barley crop in the Mariout district has never been surpassed both for quantity and quality. The crops on the Khedive’s estates at Mariout are exceptionally good.

div.head: Ancient Egyptian Skulls
div.p: The Oxford Reader in Egyptology, Mr. Randall MacIver, has been examining ancient Egyptian skulls with the result that he has discovered that the Englishman has half as large a negroid element in his constitution as the prehistoric Egyptian.

div.head: Egyptian Speculative Enterprise
div.p: “Spe- culative enterprise (remarks the “Financial Times" of the 4th inst.) on the part of the Egyptians themselves has been on a heavy scale,and so far the local demand for securities of all kinds shows no signs of slackening. It is to be hoped that the pace will be pre- vented from becoming too rapid.”

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: From the 1st Jan. to 13th inst., 194,330 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. For the corresponding period of last year the quantity was 324,589 tons. This year Newcastle sent 45,082 tons, the Welsh districts 102,954, the Scotch districts 22,749, Yorkshire 13,901, and other places 6,644 tons.

div.head: Baldness a Egypt
div.p: An inscription has been discovered showing the antiquity of baldness in Egypt Teta, King of Egypt some 3,500 years b.c., has left on record the formula of a compound designed to promote the luxuriance of his mother-in-law's hair. At this distance of time it is hard to say whether he was honestly sympathetic in his efforts, or merely the ac- complice of all ages in making sport of such unhappy victims.

div.head: New Egyptian Co.
div.p: The article from the “Financier" in our issue of Wednesday last on the position and prospects of the New Egyptian Company pointed out that, whilst the nominal share capital was £500,000 and the debenture capital £100,000, only £293,879 of the former and £55,000 of the latter had been issued up to now. The debentures, however, were referred to as Four per Cents. instead of Five per Cents., so that the yield is 1 per cent. better than was made to appear.

div.head: Employes’ Federations
div.p: The societies lately ,ormed will undoubtedly render the greatest services to this interesting class of workers. But the employes must themselves be the authors of their own prosperity, and they will most assuredly attain their object if they but apply themselves to acquiring the principal languages spoken in Egypt:-English, French, German, Arabic, Greek, Italian, etc. The Berlitz School, thanks to its unrivalled system, will enable them to thus attain their end ; a trial lesson will be sufficient to assure them of it. 25781-1

div.head: The National Hotel,
div.p: in Soliman Pasha- street, Cairo, which has been in course of construction for some time, is gradually nearing completion,and from what may be seen so far, is sure to be a great favorite with our visitors. The furniture has been ordered in England, and will be completely installed before the 1st November, the opening day of this new hotel. Both the dining-room and saloon will be sumptuously decorated, the latter in Louis XII. style, and will offer all the comfort and luxury money and modern appliances can supply. Mr. Chas. Bauer, the well-known proprietor of the Bristol Hotel, has agreed to take over the management of the National, and thus visitors may be certain of being properly attended to. The position of the new hotel, surrounded by mansions and villas, and in a quiet, aristocratic neighbour- hood, will greatly enhance its valou, and the big verandah, which is being constructed, is bound to be the meeting-place of many resi- dents and tourists during the next season.

div.head: THE HAHMAL'S RETURN. ESCORT ATTACKED BY BEDOUINS. A SHARP SKIRMISH.
div.p: The Emir el Hag telegraphs that the Mahmal, which left Yambo on the 4th March, has reached Medina. Between Yambo and Medina the escort and pilgrims were attacked by a band of Bedouins, who were successfully re- pulsed in a sharp skirmish. The Emir adds that details will follow by post.

Ibrahim Pasha Neghib, who has returned to Cairo from Tor, states that the enquiry which he opened as to the death of a Moor, who was supposed to have been killed and buried by his fellow pilgrims, resulted in the discovery that the Moor had died in alf apopletic fit. His friends, fearing that they might be suspected of poisoning, buried his body with- out informing the authorities.

The delegate of the Quarantine Board at the Hedjaz has sent a report on the pilgrimage from Yambo in which he says that the general health of the pilgrims has so far been good. Dysentery continues to prevail, while smallpox is easily spread among the pilgrims in general, and is not fought against at Yambo, where persons attacked by smallpox are dispersed everywhere. The delegate says that he himself noticed a case of small pox among the pilgrims with the Mahmal, and another was that of the wife of the doctor who accom- panied the Egyptian caravan on behalf of the Sanitary Administration.
Eight thousand pilgrims are ready to leave for Tor, five thousand of whom are Egyptian. Their condition of health is satisfactory.

div.head: THURSDAY’S RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: The child to whom the unfortunate accident happened on the railway line which we re- counted in our issue of yesterday, is the five- year-old daughter of M. Debbane, Brazilian Consul-General. The injuries which she sustain- ed are more serious than was at first believed, and as yet she cannot unfortunately be pro- nounced out of danger. It appears that the child was not knocked out of the carriage, but feel out owing to the door not being properly fastened.

Mme Debbane, who was in the carriage with her daughter, driven to despair, was only pre- vented from throwing herself on the line, in a wild desire to save her daughter, by a gentleman who happened to be in her company.

On the train being stopped, Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, Mohamed Bey Said, and Mohamed Bey Rassehm joined the other passengers in the search for the girl and gave every assistance in their power. The child had meantime been picked up by a camel-driver, who brought her to Galioub station, where first aid was admi- nistred.
The train was backed to Galioub and the child was then taken on and brought to Alex- andria, where she now lies in a dangerous condition at her father’s residence.

div.head: NEW TRAMWAY CONCESSION.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has given its approval to the scheme proposed by Boghos Pasha Nubar and M. Empain for the construc- tion of a new tramway to run along the Ismailieh Canal to the desert near Abbas- sieh. The terms of the concession are now being studied.

div.head: ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: We understand that at the ordinary meeting of the Aboukir Company, Limited, to be held in London next week, the directors will propose a dividend for the year 1904 of 7 % on the ordinary shares, and also 7 % on the deferred shares. The ordinary shares in January received a dividend of 11 % in payment of balance of arrears of their 7 % cumulative dividend.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: His Highness passed the day at Montazah Palace yesterday. He leaves for Cairo this evening, after opening the Horticultural Show at San Stefano.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: The opening regatta of the season will be held on Wednesday afternoon next, 19th inst. Members are requested to send in the entries for their boatS at onCe to the honorary secre- tary. The handicap Will be published in Tuesday afternoon's "Gazette,” as usual. It has been decided to give the prizes every four regattas instead of every three, the points to connt the same as last year.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Moeris” arrived this morn- ing from Liverpool, via Oran and Malta, with passengers and mails.

div.head: THE COLDEN GROSS LINE.
div.p: FOR CARDIFF AND BRISTOL DIRECT.
The fast steamer “Venedotian” will arrive on or about the 17th April and will have room for about 1,400 tons of cargo.
For Freight and references, please apply to Alick Nimnim & Son,
Marina, Alexandria.

div.head: OPENING OF RACING SEASON. A. S. C. SKYE MEETING.
div.p: The racing season at Alexandria opened yesterday with the Alexandria Sporting Club’s April Skye Meeting. Notwithstanding the very fine weather which prevailed, there was not a very large turn out of the public, especially in the early part of the meeting, when the grand stand bore a somewhat bare appearance. Later, however, a number of ladies graced the enclosure with their pre- sence, and more animation prevailed. In the racing the only feature of interest was the five successive wins brought about by Khalil Pasha Khayat's stable, and the owner is to be congratulated on his signal success. Jenkins rode four of the five winning mounts, acquitting himself very creditably. Though there were very good fields the finishes did not afford any excitement, with the exceptin of the Pony Stakes, which was the closest. The prettiest race of the day was the one for the Ladies’ Bracelet. There were no less than 16 starters, and all were riding coming up the straight. Pari Mutual yielded good returns, the favorites not coming up to anticipations. The following are the results of the various events, the enjoyment of which was considerably enhanced by the playing of the R. Berks. Band :—

NOVICES’ RACE of P.T. 2,500, viz : P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never run in a race of any description, Amateur races and Gymkhanas excepted. Horses 10.7, Galloways 10.3 and ponies 10.0. Distance 5 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. little Korosko, 10.0. Jenkins. 1 Mr. A. J. Sursock’s g.a.p. Flying Dutchman, 10.7. Stillwell. 2 Mr. A. J. Sursock's br.ap. Nigri, 10.3. Elias.3 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.h. Saclavie, 10.8. Ka- mel Effendi. 0 Mr. M. Tueni's ch.a.h. Ajax, 10.7. Mr. G. H. Barker. 0 Mr. Tueni's g.a.p. Hercule, 10.0. Matthews. 0 Saleh Bey Yaghen's g.a.h. Waasal, 10.7. Sha- kir. 0 Mr. K. Karam’s g.a.p. Bayard, 10.0. Michaeli- des, Jun. 0 Mr J. Hoyami’s g.a.h. Tonnerre, 10.7. Owner. 0 Mr. E. Bastros’ g.a.h. Moulk, 10.7. Fenwick. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat’s b.a.h. Zariff III. 10.7. Whiteside. 0 Moh. Pasha Chehim’s g.a.p. Derwish, 10.0. Mr. A. J. Michaelides. 0
Despatched to a good start, little Korosko led nearly all the way and won easily by two lengths. A length separated 2nd and 3rd. Time, 1.9.

Totalisator paid P.T. 58 on winner and P.T. 27, 340, and 43 for places. MAIDEN PONY PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches. Distance 1 mile.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Au Revoir, 10.10. Jenkins. 1 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Zeidan, 9.10. Whiteside. 2 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barker's g.a.p. India, 9.10. Mr. G. H. Barker. 3 Mohsen Pasha's g.a.p. Taib, 10.3. Mikhali. 0 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barker's b.a.p. Firefly, 10.7. Mr Ramsay. 0 Mr. E. Karam's g.a.p. Nimrod, 9.10. Mi- chaelides, Jun. 0 Saleh Bey Yaghen’s b.ap. Spectre, 10.8. Bonser. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.p. Sattam, lO.5 Kamel Effendi. 0 Ishak Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's c.a.p. Rais, 10.7. Stillwell. 0

A good start, all keeping well together till they entered the cutting, when Au Revoir took up the lead, followed by Taib, and Spectre. In the straight, Zeidan came to the front but could not reach Au Revoir, who won easily by about two lengths, India being a bad third. Time, 1.53 1/2.
Totalisator paid P.T. 36 on winner, and P.T. 26, 41, and 43 for places.
TRIAL PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz : P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arabs. Weight for age. Distance 6 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. Klondyke, 10.5. Jenkins. 1 Ishak Bey Hussein’s ch.a.h. El Tahawi, 10.7. Stillwell. 2 Mr. M. Tueni's b.a.h. Caprice, 10.7. Matthews. 3 Mohsen Pasha b.a.h. Gogo, 10.7. Mikhali. 0 Moharrem Pasha Chehim’s g.a.h. Jupiter, 10.6. Mr. A. J. Michaelides. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Lonlou, 10.6. Whiteside 0 Capt. G. B. Byrne’s g.a.h. Chinaman, 10.7. Moursi. 0 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barker’s b.a.h. Ion, 10.7. Mr. G. H. Barker. 0 Ishak Bey Hussein’s g.a.h. Sir Visto, 10.8. Fenwick. 0
Klondyke made most of the running and won fairly easily by a length, the others being close up. Time, 1.22 1/2.
Totalisator paid P.T. 78 on winner, and P.T. 27, 28, and 45 for places.
PONY STAKES of P.T. 2,500. 2nd horse to receive P.T. 500 out of the Stakes. For ' Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance 6 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.ap. Kawkab, 9.6. Jenkins. 1 Ishak Bey Hussein and Haasan Bey Kheir el Din’s b.a.p. Faik, 9.7. Stillwell 2 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barkers g.a.p. Vandal 10.0. Mr. G. H. Barker. 3 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.a.p. Amour, 9.3. Aly Hawass. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.p. Sattam. 9.6. Eliseo. 0 Moharrem Pasha Chehim’s g.a.p. Mamdouh, 9.2. Mr. A. J. Michaelides. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. Suleik, 9.6. White- side. 0

Amour got the best of a headstart, Suleik being left at the post. Amour was soon joined in the lead by Sattan, but on coming into the straight both horses fell back and the rest was a close race between Kawkab and Faik, the former winning by a length. Time, 1.25.
Totalizator paid P.T. 99 on winner, and P.T. 30,59, and 90 for places.

LADIES BRACELET of P.T. 2,000 present- ed by the Alexandria an Ramleh Railway Company, viz: P.T. 1,000 to the nominator of the winner and P.T. 1,000 to the owner together with P.T. 500 added to go to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never won a race except Gymkhanas. To be nominate by ladies. Horses 11.7, Ponies 10.11. Distance 6 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.h. Sinounou, 11.7. Whiteside. 1 Mr. H. Eisler’s g.a.h. Temsah, 10.11 Elias. 2 Mr. M. Tueni’s g.a.h. Faineant, 11.7 Mr. G. H. Barker. 3 Mr. A. J. Sursock’s g.a.h. Flying Dutchman, 11.7. stillwell. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat’s c.a.p. Doughan, 10.11. Jenkins. 0 Mr. E. Bustros' g.a.h. Numir, 10.11. Fenwick. 0 Moharrem Pasha Chehim’s g.a.h. Jupiter, 11.7. Mr. A.J. Michaelidis. 0 Moh. Pasha Cdhehim;s g.a.p. Dervish, 10.11. 0 Mr. M. Tueni’s g.a.p. Hercule, 10.11. Matthews. 0 Mr. E. Karam’s’ g.a.h. Boheme, 11.7. Michaeli- des Jun. 0 Sales Bey Yaghen’s g.a.h. Vassal, 11.7. Shakir. 0 Sales Bey Yaghen’s b.a.p. Spectre, 10.11 Bonser. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.a.h. Soulferino, 10.11. Eliseo. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.a.h. Azize, 11.7. Aly Hawass. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.a.h. Saclavie, 11.7. Kamel Effendi. 0

This was a very pretty race. The big field were despatched to a good start, all the horses keeping together in a cluster until entering the straight, when Temsah was seen to have gained slightly the advantage. In the straight Sinounou came through his horses and shot ahead, Temsah at his heels. He was never overtaken, however, and won by a couple of lengths. Nearing the post, Faineant came with a rush and almost wrested 2nd place from Temsah, who only got it by a head. Time, 1.24.
Totalisator paid P.T. 247 on winner, and P.T. 75, 57, and 155 for places.
APRIL PLATE of P.T. 2,500. 2nd horse to receive P.T. 500 out of the Stakes. For Arabs. Weight for age with penalties. Distance round the course.

Mr. A. J. Sursook’s g.a h. Boule de Neige, 9.4. Elias. 1 Mr. P. W. Stout’s g.a.h. Showman, 9.7. Whiteside. 2 Khalil Pasha Khayat’s g.a.p. Au Revoir, 9.7. Jenkins. 3 Mr. Teuni’s b.a.p. Caprice, 9.7. Matthews. 0 Isak Bey Hussein’s and hassan Bey Kheir el Din’s ch.a.p. Rais, 9.7. Stillwell. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s g.a.h. Royalist, 9.7. Kamel Effendi. 0 Mr. E. Karam’s ch.a.h. Coeur de Lion, 9.7. Michaelides, Jun. 0 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H.Barker’s ch.a.h. Shari, 9.7, Mr. G. H. Barker. 0

The horses got away to a good start, Mash- kour and Coeur de Lion leading. When reaching the mile post, Coeur de Lion still maintained the premier position, with Royalist in close attendance. On entering the cutting Boule de Neige challenged the leader and was first into the straight, where all were riding. Coeur de Lion was now done with and although Au Revoir at one time looked like winning, Boule de Neige got first past the post by barely a length, Au Revoir being some distance behind Shewiman. Time, 2.35.
Totalisator paid P.T. 48 on winner, and P.T. 27, 76, and 36 for places.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
ARRIVALS.
div.p: Per Moss S.S. "Moeris,” arrived to-day from Liverpool :-Mr. H.B. Johnston, Pte W. Salt, Pte W. Skillett, and 4 deck passengers.

Lo paquobot "Salaria" des Messageries Ma- ritimes parti hier pour Marseille avait a bord. M. et Mme Beyram Bey et Mustafa Bayram Bey, M. et Mme Barbier, M. et Mme Gutmann, M. Specht, Mme Hatter, M. le Dr Kenneth Scott, Mme Kenneth Scott, Mme H. S. Gaze, Mlle Rich, M. et Mme G. Watson, M. le Dentu, M. de Heredia, M. et Mme J. L. Baird, Cap. Cave, Mme Bernard, M. Mathews, Mme Susznna Valmont, M. J. Rapaport, Madame Fillion, Madame Royet, M. Thomas, Mrs. G. R. et A. Huri et sa dame, Mlle Kheror, Mme Myrthes, Mme Dorey, M. div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Weissentein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch Matroi ; Station, Liens (reached from Venice or Trieate). Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing, best June and September. Prospectuses and Pho- to graphs, “Egyptian Gazette” office, Cairo.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly, brother of the Khedive, arrived at Constantinople on Monday last. His Highness went straight to the Imperial Palace, and afterward, to the Yali of the Khedivah Mother at Bebek, where he is at present re- siding.
Prince Aziz Pasha Hassen and Zeky Pasha arrived at Alexandria from Cairo last evening.
Abdul Halim Pasha Assem, Director-General of the Wakfs Administration, has left for Cairo.
M. de la Bouliniere, French Diplomatic Agent, arrived from Cairo yesterday. He is staying with M. P. Girard, French Consul at Alexandria.
Councillor A. C. Cumbo leaves today for Brindisi by the "Semiramis." He intends to spend the Easter holidays at Rome with his family and will be back in Alexandria in three weeks.
The marriage arranged between Miss Mary Prior and Mr. William H. E. Quintana will take place at St. Catherine's Cathedral Alex- andria, on Monday, 24th inst., at 2 p.m.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at Alexandria yesterday, of M. Gregoire Mistrovachi. The funeral of deceased, who was a chevalier of the Order of Francis- Joseph, took place this morning, at the Greek Orthodox cemetery,
We have received P.T. 50 from Mme. Vve. H. Gantse and a like amount from Mr. E. C. Manuk, for the St. Vincent de Paul charity, in memory of the late M. Mistrovachi.

div.head: ALL SAINTS’ CHURCH, CAIRO.
div.p: On Monday, Tueday, Wednesday, and Thurs- day, April 17th to 20th the Services will be as follows:— 8.30 a.m. Holy Communion. 10.30 “ Morning prayer. 6.30 p.m. Evensong and Address.
On Good Friday 8.30 a.m. Ante-Communion. 10.30 „ Morning Prayer and Sermon. 2.— p.m. One hour Service. 6.- “ Evening Prayer and Sermon.
On Easter Eve Holy Communion 8.30 a.m. Morning Prayer 10.30 „
On EASTER DAY Holy Communion 6.30 a.m. 7.30 a.m. 8.30 a.m. and after Morning Service. Other Servicee as on Sundays.
On Easter Monday and Tuesday Holy Communion 8.30 a.m.
Offertory on Good Friday will be devoted to the Jerusalem and the East Mission Fund.

div.head: ST. MARK'S, ALEXANDRIA. HOLY WEEK.
div.p: Monday to Thursday inclusive 8 a.m. Holy Communion. 11 a.m. Morning Prayer and Address. 5.30 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
Good Friday. 8 am. Ante-Communion Service. 11 a.m. Morning Player, Litany, and Sermon. 6.15 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
Easter Eve. 8 a.m. Ante-Communion Service
EASTER DAY. Three Celebrations of the Holy Com- munion, 7 a.m. 8 a.m. and Noon. 11 a.m. Matins and Sermon. 6.15 a.m. Evensong and Sermon.

div.head: ALL SAINTS’ RAMLEH. HOLY WEEK.
div.p: Monday to Thursday inclusive: 8 a.m. Holy Communion. 6 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
Good Friday. 8 a.m. Ante-Communion Service. 11 a.m. Morning Prayer, Litany, and Sermon. 6.30 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
EASTER DAY. The Holy Communion will be celebrated at 7.30 a.m., 8.30 am. and at noon, in addition to the usual services at 11 am. 3.30 p.m. and 6.30. p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Auiourd’hui a midi et demie)
div.p: Le marche en general se maintient dans les positions acquises. Certaines valeurs accusent meme une hausse notable ; entre autres, la Daira et la Crown Brewery. Quant aux transac- tions, elles ont ete assez nombreuses, en parti- culier en Daira et en Salt and Soda.
La Daira debute a 27 3/8, et atteint 28 pour cloturer achetersn a 27 15/16 avec tendance marquee a la hausse.
De 210 la Crown Brewery passe en raison d’une forte demands a 220, prix anquel elle cloture acheteurs.
De 38/8 al’ouverture la Salt and Soda a’eleve graduellement a 39/83 en cloture avec beau- coup d’affaires.
Il y a du mieux aussi en Investment a 2 3/16, en Oasis a 1 838 et an Privileglees Tram- ways a 147 1/2.
Par contre la Nungovich est plus fiable a 10 1/4 l’Anglo American Nile a 5 13/16, la Delta Light a 14 1/8 et la Ramleh Railway a 8 3/16.
